p:
However, exogenous pathogens are not dominant members of the oral microbiome, which is one of the most diverse in the human body with over 20 billion microbial cells.
40 Moreover, in states of health, a robust interbacterial interaction limits or reduces colonization with exogenous pathogens. For instance, bacteriocins such as LS1 (produced by the oral commensal Lactobacillus salivarius) contribute to controlling the growth of S. aureus and S. pneumoniae,
41 ,
42 and hydrogen peroxide (which is produced by several commensal species) prevents colonization by Serratia marcescens, S. agalactiae, S. pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae and MRSA.
43 ,
44
